{{Use dmy|date=January 2017}}{{Use British English|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox television | show_name = Rot op met je religie | image = Rot op met je religie.jpg | caption = | show_name_2 = | genre = [[Reality show]], [[religion]] | creator = | developer = | writer = | director = | creative_director = | presenter = Kefah Allush | starring = | judges = | voices = | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = | country = [[Netherlands]] | language = [[Dutch language|Dutch]] | num_seasons = 1 | num_episodes = 5 | list_episodes = | executive_producer = | producer = Tuvalu Media | editor = | location = [[Haarlem]] and elsewhere in the [[Netherlands]] | cinematography = | camera = | runtime = 40 minutes | company = [[Evangelische Omroep|EO]] | distributor = | channel = [[NPO 2]] | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_run = | first_aired = 16 January 2017 | last_aired = 20 January 2017 | status = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = | website = http://www.eo.nl/home/over-de-eo/pers/item/artikel/rot-op-met-je-religie/ | production_website = }}
'''''Rot op met je religie''''' (English: ''To Hell With Your Religion'') is a 2017 [[Netherlands|Dutch]] television series by the [[Evangelische Omroep]], presented by Kefah Allush.
== Setting and purpose == In this [[Reality television|reality show]], four [[religion|religious people]] (two [[Christianity|Christians]], a [[Islam|Muslim]] and a [[Judaism|Jew]]) and two [[atheism|atheists]] live together in the same house in [[Haarlem]], and discuss and debate their religious beliefs, practices and traditions.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j7LJvru7g4U |title=De Nieuwe Maan - Rot op met je religie |work=De Nieuwe Maan |publisher=[[Omroep NTR|NTR]] |date=14 January 2017 |accessdate=16 January 2017}}</ref> It features mutual [[criticism of religion]] as well as [[interfaith dialogue]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.eo.nl/home/over-de-eo/pers/item/artikel/rot-op-met-je-religie/ |title=Rot op met je religie |author=Thimo den Hartog |publisher=Evangelische Omroep |accessdate=16 January 2017}}</ref> The participants also travel across the Netherlands to visit [[Place of worship|houses of worship]], an [[abortion clinic]] and a [[Dhabihah|halal]] [[slaughterhouse]] amongst other places, and cook together despite their widely varying ethical views on food.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.telegraaf.nl/filmenuitgaan/rtv/26697584/__EO__Rot_op_met_je_geloof__.html |title=EO: Rot op met je geloof |author=Marcel Frost |work=[[De Telegraaf]] |date=28 September 2016 |accessdate=16 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.eo.nl/home/over-de-eo/pers/item/artikel/de-ultieme-religiestress-test-in-rot-op-met-je-religie-op-npo2/ |title=De ultieme religiestress-test in ‘Rot op met je religie’ op NPO2 |publisher=Evangelische Omroep |date=6 January 2017 |accessdate=16 January 2017}}</ref>
The EO hopes the programme will show what 'religious stress'<ref>The neologism ''religiestress'' ("religious stress") was coined in 2012 by Dutch theologian Tom Mikkers, who works for the EO.</ref> does to the candidates, and what effect this has on their beliefs. Just before the first episode was broadcast, the EO published a survey about religious stress amongst Dutch citizens, which showed amongst other things that 93% of the population is in favour of [[freedom of speech]], and 82% supports [[freedom of religion]], but almost half think that [[secularism|religion should not be professed in public]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.rd.nl/kerk-religie/eo-nederlanders-ervaren-dilemma-s-rond-religie-1.1365904 |title=EO: Nederlanders ervaren dilemma’s rond religie |work=[[Reformatorisch Dagblad]] |date=12 January 2017 |accessdate=16 January 2017}}</ref> Previously, the EO made similar programmes about [[refugee]]s (''Rot op naar je eigen land'', "Piss Off To Your Own Country", 2015) and [[environmental issue]]s (''[[Rot op met je milieu]]'', "Get Lost With Your Environment", 2016).<ref name="Heesakkers">{{Cite news |url=http://www.volkskrant.nl/televisie/een-hoop-pleuris-en-religiestress-in-rot-op-met-je-religie~a4450288/ |title=Een hoop pleuris en religiestress in 'Rot op met je religie' |author=Gidi Heesakkers |work=[[de Volkskrant]] |date=18 January 2017 |accessdate=19 January 2017}}</ref>
== Participants == {| class= "wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" |- ! Name ! Worldview |- | Jan | Christian ([[Baptists|Baptist]]) |- | Sheila | Jewish ([[Reform Judaism|Liberal Jew]]) |- | Safeer | Muslim ([[Ahmadiyya]]) |- | Dineke | Christian ([[Dutch Reformed Church|Dutch Reformed]]) |- | Bryan | atheist |- | [[Floris van den Berg|Floris]] | atheist ([[De Vrije Gedachte|Freethinker]] and [[veganism|vegan]]) |}
== Reception == Stichting KijkOnderzoek, a [[Nielsen ratings|ratings tracking]] service, reported that about 531,000 people watched the first episode.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.nieuwwij.nl/nieuws/ruim-half-miljoen-kijkers-rot-op-religie/ |title=Ruim half miljoen kijkers voor 'Rot op met je religie' |work=NieuwWij.nl |date=17 January 2017 |accessdate=17 January 2017}}</ref>
According to ''[[NRC Handelsblad]]'', the EO used the programme to deliberately fan the flames of religious stress, and by their selection of participants created an unfair representation of the various worldviews: "The [[casting]] wants us to primarily look for reasonableness amongst the four religious participants (...). Even the two non-believers clash occasionally, because one is [[veganism|vegan]] and the other finds that to be politically correct bullshit. In short: in the first episode, the religious stress isn't quite fairly distributed yet between the followers of [[God]] and those who reject the existence of the fairytale character of god."<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nrc.nl/nieuws/2017/01/17/de-eo-stookt-de-religiestress-nog-op-6246021-a1541592 |title=De EO stookt de religiestress verder op |author=Hans Beerekamp |work=[[NRC Handelsblad]] |date=17 January 2017 |accessdate=17 January 2017}}</ref>
After three episodes, ''[[de Volkskrant]]'', too, concluded that "the EO does everything within their power to let all hell break loose. There is no live and let live." Just like in the previous ''Rot op'' series, the programme would primarily be "about confrontation, heated discussions and perhaps a vain hope of reconciliation." It noted that the most fierce nonbeliever, Floris, "is portrayed the least sympathetic by the montage so far." On the preview of the fourth episode, in which Safeer shows his unease when meeting a [[Islam and homosexuality|gay Muslim]], the newspaper's reviewer (referencing [[Genesis 1:4]]) commented: "Someone saw the announcement, and saw it was not good. ''Stress!''" <ref name="Heesakkers"/>
A critic from ThePostOnline disagreed with the ''Volkskrant'''s criticism of the montage: "By definition, media select that which is appetising." On the contrary, 'sensational television' is interesting, especially to discover who 'understands the art of living and tolerance best'. In his opinion, the atheist and vegan Floris, "whose raised voice against his religious fellow man may go into Dutch television history as legendary", drawing the comparison to the late politician [[Pim Fortuyn]], finishes last in this regard, followed by the imam Safeer, whilst sympathy for the atheist Bryan is growing throughout the series, and the Jewish Sheila has had the audience's sympathy from the beginning. Furthermore, the EO allegedly lacked a sense of humour, and the idea of 'let it be' would only rarely feature in the show.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://media.tpo.nl/2017/01/19/rot-op-religie-minder-minder-minder-veganisten/ |title=Rot op met je religie: Minder, minder, minder veganisten |author=Peter Olsthoorn |work=ThePostOnline |date=19 January 2017 |accessdate=20 January 2017}}</ref>

{{Traditional African religion}} [[Traditional African religions]] have shared notable relationships with other religions, cultures, and traditions.
Throughout the history, they are often noted for having one of the oldest presence in the world, and also applauded for its tolerance with other religions.<ref>{{cite book|title = Religious Plurality in Africa: Essays in Honour of John S. Mbiti|page = 67|publisher = [[Walter de Gruyter]]|year = 1993}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title = Africa Since 1935|author = Ali AlʼAmin Mazrui, Christophe Wondji|page = 502|year = 1993|publisher = University of California Press|isbn = 9780435948146}}</ref>
== Hinduism ==
Like [[Hinduism]], the traditional African religion recognizes the presence of one supreme deity as well as the existence of God in multiple aspects.<ref>{{cite book|title = A Tribute to Hinduism: Thoughts and Wisdom Spanning Continents and Time about India and Her Culture|author = Sushama Londhe|page = 79|year = 2008}}</ref>
Traditional [[Igbo_mythology|Igbo]] doctrine of [[reincarnation]] and connection to the spiritual mortal identity of the culture, themes about spiritual instrumentality based on the traditional Igobo beliefs and practices with the Hindu mantra, specifically the doctrine in the creative power of the spoken word are identical.<ref>"Gendering Global Transformations: Gender, Culture, Race, and Identity", p. 114, by Chima J. Korieh, Philomina E Okeke-Ihejirika, publisher = Routledge</ref>
== Christianity == {{further|Afro-American religion}} God is esteemed by both African religion and [[Christianity]] as both the very ground being, and the necessary of life, and any form of being or existence, such as the creation itself. Anthropology is the basic starting place for both religions, human beings are the temporal mirrors and mediators (imago Dei) of God in the feature world.<ref>{{cite book|title = African religion, philosophy, and Christianity in Logos-Christ: common ground revisited|author = Emmanuel K. Twesigye|page = 9|publisher = Peter Lang Publishing|year = 1996}}</ref>
The Christian idea of church has similarities with African traditional life in which brotherhood and the extended family play a central role. The Church is the Christian family, in which all are accompanied to one another through belief and baptism in [[Jesus Christ]]. The Church also combines those who have died and those who still live. This is parallel view to the African view of the family of both the living and the omitted.<ref>"Introduction to African Religion", by John S. Mbiti, p. 190 publisher = Heinemann, [https://books.google.com/books?id=i9ezVqxxxqgC&pg=PA190#v=onepage&q&f=false]</ref>
== Islam ==
African traditional religion is also regarded to have influenced [[Islam]], but despite this African customs were simply rejected by the Muslims. Muslim missionaries in Africa have often used violence as a means of conversion.<ref>{{cite book|title = The Wiley-Blackwell Companion to African Religions|page=328|author=Elias Kifon Bongmba|publisher=John Wiley & Sons}}</ref> It also notable that before the expansion of Islam, [[human sacrifice]]s were common in [[Egypt]], Egyptians conducted to sacrifice female to River Nile, every year when it was flooded. The flood would remain until a young female was thrown into it as a sacrifice. During the reign of Caliph [[Umar|Umar bin al-Khattab]], Amr bin al-Aas, the governor of Egypt, wrote to Umar askin his direction for such activity. There is a story that Umar answered by writing a note to be thrown into the Nile river instead of sacrificing a female to it. The note enclosed verses from the Qur'an and a command from Umar asking the Nile to flow fluently in the name of Allah without causing any damage to inhabitants. When the note was thrown into the Nile, the flood dissolved. After that they won't sacrifice human.<ref>p. 329 - 330 by Elias Kifon Bongmba</ref>
Today, even after the suppression of African traditional religion, the religion has its notable traces in northern Africa. Followers of African religion in Muslim dominated areas can be found, adhering their beliefs, rituals, magic, medicines. Generally they have adopted the [[Islam and clothing|Muslim way of dressing]] but in matter of deeper subjects such as life, birth, marriage, death, they remain the followers of African religion.<ref>"An Introduction to African Religion (2nd Edition)", by John S. Mbiti, p. 191 publisher = East African Publishers</ref>
==Buddhism==
Relations of African religion with [[Buddhism]] dates back to 17th century. After the establishment of the Dutch settlement at [[Cape Agulhas]], some Buddhists paid short, coincidental visits to the Cape Agulhas - such as the few Thai monks who were aboard the Portuguese ship which ran aground off.<ref>{{cite book|title = A World of Religions: A South African Perspective|publisher = Kagiso Publishers|year = 1996|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DCAvAAAAYAAJ|author = Piet Meiring}}</ref>
Like Hinduism, [[Akan religion|Akan]] tradition shares belief in reincarnation with Buddhism.<ref>{{cite book|title = Cross-Cultural Visions in African American Literature: West Meets East|publisher =[[Palgrave Macmillan]]|author = Yoshinobu Hakutani|page = 5}}</ref>

Gbenda, 1997 * ''African Traditional Religion in South Africa: An Annotated Bibliography'' by David Chidester [https://books.google.com/books?id=8rGpO_TzeCsC&pg=PA48#v=onepage&q&f=false]

[[File:Volunteer Ministers.jpg|thumb|right|200px|A logo used by the Volunteer Ministers program]] A '''Volunteer Minister''' (VM) is a member of [[Scientology]] sent to a [[disaster zone]] to spread the doctrine of Scientology and provide disaster relief.<ref name="3 methods" /><ref name="Dissem Tips" /><ref name="HCOPL 22-2-91"/> The program was created in the 1970s by Scientology founder [[L. Ron Hubbard]]. As of 2016, The volunteer ministers has a network of over 9,000 trained ministers.<ref name="Roux">{{cite book |last=Roux |first1=Eric |title=Cult Wars in Historical Perspective: New and Minority Religions |chapter=Scientology |editor-last=Gallagher |editor-first=Eugene V. |publisher=Routledge |date=21 July 2016 |isbn=978-1472458124 }}</ref>
The Church of Scientology says that the program constitutes "the only effective steps to arrest and reverse the deterioration of [the] world",<ref name="HCOPL 22-2-91">Hubbard, "Volunteer Ministers," HCO Policy Letter 22 February 1991</ref> but critics argue that [[Scientology]] uses the program to gain positive media attention and recruit new members (known within Scientology as 'raw meat').<ref>{{cite news |title=[[The Thriving Cult of Greed and Power]] |accessdate=12 September 2012 |newspaper=TIME Magazine |date=6 May 1991 |author=Richard Behar}}</ref><ref name="FiveLive">{{cite news | title = Reporter Elodie Harper goes undercover to reveal the tactics used by Scientology followers in the immediate aftermath of traumatic events. | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio/aod/networks/fivelive/aod.shtml?fivelive/flreport_scientologynew | format = Real Audio (45 min) | work = [[BBC Radio 5 Live|Five Live Report]] | publisher = [[BBC Radio]] | date = 2006-07-02 | accessdate = 2008-03-28}}</ref><ref name="NMHA"/>
Controversy over the group's goals and activities notwithstanding,<ref name="FiveLive" /><ref name="NMHA">"[http://www1.nmha.org/newsroom/system/news.vw.cfm?do=vw&rid=341 Beware Scientologists Claiming To Be Mental Health Professionals]," official statement, [[Mental Health America|National Mental Health Association]], September 17, 2001 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927024155/http://www1.nmha.org/newsroom/system/news.vw.cfm?do=vw&rid=341 |date=September 27, 2007 }}</ref> one local official in India welcomed their assistance.<ref name=Touch>{{cite web | first = Peter S. | last = Goodman | title = For Tsunami Survivors, A Touch of Scientology | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A43291-2005Jan27.html | work = [[Washington Post]] | date = 2005-01-28 | accessdate = 2008-03-28 }}</ref>
==Objectives== According to Hubbard, the objective of the program is to "put basic [[Dianetics]] and [[Scientology]] technology into view and into use at the raw public level."<ref name="FBDL 424">Hubbard, "The Volunteer Ministers Program," Flag Bureau Data Letter 424, 11 July 1974</ref> In Hubbard's words, ''The Volunteer Minister's Handbook'' "will be broadly distributed on Scn and non-Scientology lines, bought by the man on the street. He'll use some of the data, produce some miracles, save a marriage or two, rescue some kid from drugs, help his next door neighbor who's upset because her child's failing in school and couldn't care less, plus brighten up her yawning of Spring and teach him to study, and handle Aunt Martha's dizziness with assists."<ref name="FBDL 424"/>
Each Volunteer Minister pays to attend a two-week course and purchase Scientology materials; in 1994, these materials cost $435.<ref name="WarmCold">{{cite news|last=Garcia|first=Wayne|title=WANTED // WARM HEARTS, COLD CASH|newspaper=St. Petersburg Times|date=29 May 1994|quote=Scientologists who enroll as volunteer ministers buy a $100 handbook and take a $335 course on how to use the book}}</ref> The book is called ''The Scientology Handbook'' and is 968 pages long.<ref name="WarmCold"/>
Scientology spokesman Eric Roux writes: “A Scientology volunteer minister is trained to bring spiritual assistance to anyone in any aspect of life, whether it is to increase his communication ability, his study skills, help raising children or save marriages, as well as dozens of other domains of intervention.”<ref>{{cite news | title = French court convicts Church of Scientology of fraud | url = http://www.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/europe/10/27/france.scientology.fraud/index.html | work = CNN | date = October 27, 2009 | accessdate = March 26, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Roux"/>
==Origins== {{Rquote|right|He should represent himself to the person or the person's family as a minister whose compassion was compelled by the newspaper story concerning the person|[[L. Ron Hubbard]]|<ref name="3 methods" />}} The program is the successor to earlier Scientology outreach efforts, notably the "Casualty Contact" program for recruiting new Scientologists (called "[[preclear]]s") from hospitals, the scenes of accidents and other places where people might have experienced trauma. As Hubbard put it, "One takes every daily paper he can get his hands on and cuts from it every story whereby he might have a preclear. [...] He should represent himself to the person or the person's family as a minister whose compassion was compelled by the newspaper story concerning the person. [...]."<ref name="3 methods">Hubbard, "Three methods of dissemination," Professional Auditor's Bulletin 73, 28 February 1956.</ref>
Hubbard advised that "using his minister's card, an auditor need only barge into any non-sectarian hospital, get permission to visit the wards from the superintendent, mentioning nothing about processing but only about taking care of people's souls."<ref name="Dissem Tips">Hubbard, "Dissemination Tips," HCO Bulletin 15 September 1959</ref> The primary objective was simply to recruit more members for Scientology: "Some small percentage of the persons visited or their families will turn up in his group. Thus he will build a group and naturally from that group he will get a great many individual preclears."<ref name="3 methods"/> This was, however, not how the program was to be presented to the general public: "A great many miracles will follow in his wake and he is later to become a subject of the press himself. However, in handling the press we should simply say that it is a mission of the Church to assist those who are in need of assistance."<ref name="Dissem Tips"/>
The Volunteer Ministers program is also intended to operate as a recruitment activity. As Hubbard puts it,
:As the benefits of the Volunteer Minister program begin to spread throughout the society, a rank and file of people that have been helped will begin to accumulate. These people will begin to feed into [[Scientology Missions International|missions]] and Churches of Scientology from wherever the Volunteer Minister has been at work.<ref name="HCOPL 22-2-91"/>
==Organizational aspects== [[Image:Gulttält1.jpg|thumb|250px|Scientology volunteer minister tent in Sweden, October 2008]] In recent years, the Church of Scientology has heavily promoted and greatly increased the profile and size of the Volunteer Ministers program. Church publications say that there are over 95,000 Volunteer Ministers - more than the [[Peace Corps]], [[Americorps]] and [[United Nations]] volunteer programs combined.<ref>The Bridge, Magazine of the Church of Scientology of Sydney. Issue 385, April 2006</ref> The Church has set a target of recruiting as many Volunteer Ministers as there are policemen in each of the principal countries in which Scientology is active. In 2001, the Church announced a number of target quotas for Volunteer Minister recruitment, as follows:<ref>"Cause" magazine, Magazine of the International Ecclesiastical League of Pastors (I HELP), December 2001</ref>
{| |- align=right | '''Country''' |   '''Total inhabitants''' |   '''Quota for VMs''' |- align=right | Australia | 18,783,551 | 58,229 |- align=right | Austria | 8,139,299 | 5,231 |- align=right | Canada | 31,006,347 | 6,118 |- align=right | Denmark | 5,356,845 | 6,603 |- align=right | France | 58,978,172 | 82,831 |- align=right | Germany | 82,087,361 | 254,469 |- align=right | Italy | 56,735,130 | 175,878 |- align=right | Sweden | 8,911,296 | 27,624 |- align=right | United States | 272,639,608 | 845,184 |}
However, an ARIS demographic study by the City University of New York (CUNY) estimated in 2000 that there may only be 55,000 Scientologists in the whole of the United States.<ref>Kosmin, Barry A. [http://www.gc.cuny.edu/faculty/research_briefs/aris/key_findings.htm American Religious Identification Survey] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070320221156/http://www.gc.cuny.edu/faculty/research_briefs/aris/key_findings.htm |date=2007-03-20 }} (accessed April 20, 2006)</ref>
==Recent activities==
[[File:Scientology Volunteer Ministers in Haiti 2010.jpg|thumb|Scientology Volunteer Ministers in Haiti 2010]][[File:Scientology Volunteer Ministers doing medical work in Haiti 2010.jpg|thumb|Scientology Volunteer Ministers in Haiti 2010]][[File:Scientology Volunteer Minister Ship Hornbeam arriving in Haiti.jpg|thumb|Scientology Volunteer Minister Ship Hornbeam arriving in Haiti]]Volunteer Ministers have frequently been sent to the scenes of major disasters, where they distribute [[Scientology]] pamphlets and purport to heal or relieve pain using Scientology techniques such as "Locationals," "Nerve assists" and "[[Touch assist]]s."<ref name=Touch/><ref>[http://www.scientologyhandbook.org/sh6_4.htm Explanation of a touch assist from the Scientology Handbook]</ref>
Volunteer Ministers have been sent to the site of relief efforts in Southeast Asia in the wake of the [[2004 Indian Ocean earthquake|December 2004 tsunami]]<ref>Deseret News, "[http://www.deseretnews.com/article/600114811/Salt-Lake-volunteer-brought-healing-to-Indonesians.html]." 26 February 2005</ref> and to [[London Underground]] stations that were attacked in the [[7 July 2005 London bombings]]. Eight hundred were sent to [[New Orleans]] and the [[Gulf Coast]] following [[Hurricane Katrina]].<ref>Associated Press, "[http://www.katc.com/Global/story.asp?S=4903427 Scientology missions spring up in hurricane-damaged areas]." 15 May 2006 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928065429/http://www.katc.com/Global/story.asp?S=4903427 |date=September 28, 2007 }}</ref> In 2012, news broke that Volunteer Ministers were providing [[Purification Rundown|purification rundowns]] in [[Vietnam]] to people who had been exposed to [[Agent Orange]];<ref>{{cite news|title=Agent Orange victims get Scientology treatment|newspaper=[[New York Times]] via Indian Express|date=7 September 2012}}</ref> doctors and researchers criticized the Agent Orange treatments as "unscientific and unproven" and said that they "could be harmful".<ref>{{cite news|last=Fuller|first=Thomas|title=Scientology methods used to treat Agent Orange victims|newspaper=International Herald Tribune|date=5 September 2012}}</ref>
Volunteer Ministers have provided assists to relief personnel following [[September 11 attacks]] in New York.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Clarke|first1=Peter Bernard|title=New Religions in Global Perspective: A Study of Religious Change in the Modern World|date=2006|publisher=Psychology Press|isbn=9780415257480|page=123}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Reitman|first1=Janet|title=Inside Scientology: The Story of America's Most Secretive Religion|date=2011|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Harcourt}}</ref>
The Volunteer Ministers have also worked in Mississippi, Alabama and Louisiana after hurricanes Katrina and Rita, in the 2010 Haiti earthquake, in the Pakistan flood in 2010, in the Fukushima earthquake in 2011, and the May 2014 floods in Bosnia.<ref name="Roux"/>
==Controversy==
As with many of the Church of Scientology's programs, the Volunteer Ministers have generated controversy and criticism. The organization provides "spiritual relief" parallel with medical treatment, but also does simple tasks such as helping cleanup or fetch food and generally assist the disaster effort as seems indicated.{{citation needed|date=April 2014}} They have been accused of attempting to take advantage of disasters in order to promote Scientology to a grief-stricken populace.<ref>{{cite web | first = Janaka | last = Perera | title = Scientology: Cult of greed in divine garb | url = http://www.asiantribune.com/news/2005/06/10/scientology-cult-greed-divine-garb | work = [[Asian Tribune]] | date = 2005-06-10 | accessdate = 2008-12-07 }}</ref> Church of Scientology insists that assists are given parallel to medical treatment, not in place of it; the Handbook for Scientology Assists stresses in its basic guidelines: "Always seek first aid and medical attention when needed. An assist is not a substitute for medical attention or treatment by a qualified doctor. First, call the doctor. Then assist the person as you can."<ref>L. Ron Hubbard "Assists Processing Handbook" page 8</ref>
The Volunteer Minister program most heavily promoted by Scientology took place in the immediate aftermath of the 9/11 attacks. Critics of Scientology accused the organization of attempting to take advantage of the disaster in order to promote Scientology to the grief-stricken populace in the area. The National Mental Health Association issued a public warning in response to the conduct of Scientologists in the immediate aftermath of September 11, claiming that Scientologists were "Intentionally confusing [the] public" by presenting themselves as mental health service providers. According to NMHA President Michael M. Faenza, "The public needs to understand that the Scientologists are using this tragedy to recruit new members. They are not providing mental health assistance."<ref name="NMHA" />
In Russia, after the [[Beslan school hostage crisis]] tragedy in 2004, the Health Ministry ordered Scientologists out of the area, saying "that various psychological tactics the groups use, including what it called hypnosis, may be harmful not only for adults, but for children that have already suffered severe mental shock."<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.mosnews.com/news/2004/10/12/scientologybeslan.shtml | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20041016034857/http://www.mosnews.com/news/2004/10/12/scientologybeslan.shtml | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 2004-10-16 | title = Health Ministry Asks Police to Shut Down Church of Scientology in Beslan | accessdate = 2006-10-21 | date = 2004-10-12 | publisher = MosNews }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.mosnews.com/news/2004/10/22/scientologists.shtml | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20041031024305/http://www.mosnews.com/news/2004/10/22/scientologists.shtml | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 2004-10-31 | title = Scientologists Sent Packing from Beslan — Police | accessdate = 2006-10-21 | date = 2004-10-22 | publisher = MosNews }}</ref>
In the [[United Kingdom]], Volunteer Ministers played a similar role in the aftermath of the [[7 July 2005 London bombings]], targeting the families of victims and emergency workers. As in the United States in 2001, this resulted in controversy, and it was reported that Volunteer Ministers had been removed from the vicinity of survivors of the bus bombing in Tavistock Square.<ref>{{Cite news|title=7/7 War on Britain: Sick Comfort|work=[[Daily Mirror]]|date=12 July 2005|first=Stephen|last=Moyes|pages=10|location=London|quote=At the bus-bomb scene, 12 Scientologists in yellow T- shirts carrying the words Volunteer Minister were ushered away from survivors.}}</ref> It later emerged that the [[Metropolitan Police]] had agreed to give the Church of Scientology privileged access to the Police Message Broadcasting System, enabling the Church to dispatch Volunteer Minister rapid-response teams in the event of future emergencies in the capital.<ref>{{cite web | title = Met allows Cruise's sect access to data on security alerts | url = http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/showbiz/article-23389685-details/article.do | work = | publisher = [[Evening Standard]] | date = 2007-03-20 | accessdate = 2008-03-28 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080407213023/http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/showbiz/article-23389685-details/article.do | archive-date = 2008-04-07 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref>
Paul Fletcher, director of the London branch of [[Citizens Commission on Human Rights|CCHR]] and Stefania Cisco, a Director of Special Affairs for Scientology, admitted to an undercover [[BBC]] reporter that the purpose of the volunteer ministers was to keep the psychiatrists away, and called this "spiritual security".<ref name="FiveLive"/><ref>[http://www.newsfrombree.co.uk/stolgy_25.htm Transcript of BBC Radio report on Volunteer Ministers, 2 July 2006]</ref>
After the [[Virginia Tech massacre]], April 16, 2007, 20 Volunteer Ministers were on the campus.<ref>{{cite news | author = George Rush |author2=Joanna Rush Molloy | title = Critics: Scientologists' Va. trip a time to prey | url = http://www.nydailynews.com/gossip/r_m/2007/04/18/2007-04-18_critics_scientologists_va_trip_a_time_to.html | publisher = [[NY Daily News]] | date = 2007-04-17 | accessdate = 2007-05-16}}</ref> Bulletins to Scientology members said that help had been requested by the university provost, the [[Salvation Army]] and the [[Red Cross]], but these organizations denied that any requests had been made. The activities of the Volunteer Ministers at Virginia Tech was reported to have received strong criticism from local pastors.<ref>{{cite news |first=John |last=Cook |title=Slinging Scientology, Mud on VT Campus |url=http://www.radaronline.com/exclusives/2007/04/as-we-reported-friday-the.php |work=Fresh Intelligence |publisher=[[Radar (magazine)|Radar Online]] |date=2007-04-24 |accessdate=2007-05-16 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070501225738/http://www.radaronline.com/exclusives/2007/04/as-we-reported-friday-the.php |archivedate=2007-05-01 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name="podger">{{cite news | first = Pamela J. | last = Podger | title = Scientologists visiting Va. Tech to help | url = http://www.roanoke.com/vtcampus/wb/114629 | work = | publisher = [[The Roanoke Times]] | date = 2007-04-26 | accessdate = 2007-05-16 | archive-url = https://archive.is/20130201110720/http://www.roanoke.com/vtcampus/wb/114629 | archive-date = 2013-02-01 | dead-url = yes | df = }}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Infobox religion | name = [[File:Weixinism symbol.svg|70px]]
Weixinism
唯心聖教 ''Wéixīn Shèngjiào'' | image = Hsien Fo Temple, Taiwan.jpg | imagewidth = 200px | caption = Hsien Fo Temple, Taiwan | founder = Grand Master Hun Yuan (1944–) | scripture = Collection of scriptures from the Chinese religio-philosophical tradition; ''Apocalypse Scriptures'' and ''Weixin Canon'' by Grand Master Hun Yuan | members = 300,000 core members, estimated 1 million more followersIntrovigne (2016). | website = http://cjs.tw/ }} '''Weixinism''' (唯心教 ''Wéixīnjiào''), institutionally also known by the extended title of '''Holy Church of the Heart-Only''' (唯心聖教 ''Wéixīn Shèngjiào'') is one of the [[Chinese salvationist religions]] born in [[Taiwan]] in the late 20th century. It was founded in 1984 in [[Taichung]] by [[Grand Master Hun Yuan]]. Its global core membership is "about 300,000, with a larger audience estimated by Taiwan's Ministry of Internal Affairs at 1,000,000".Introvigne (2016). The church has quickly spread to mainland [[China]] since the early 2000s, where it functions as a platform for joint initiatives of the Chinese mainland and Taiwanese governments for the renewal of Chinese culture. It has also developed as a worldwide religious movement, attracting followers not only from the Chinese diaspora, but also communities of other races, including East Asians and even Westerners.Introvigne (2016). Weixinism operates a synthesis and reproposition for the modern times of ancient [[Chinese folk religion|Chinese religion]] and [[philosophy]], primarily focused on the "orthodox lineages of ''[[Yijing]]'' and ''[[fengshui]]''","[http://hunyuan.tw/m/?disp=pwpeace&language=ENG&page=5 Weixinism propagates Chinese culture and Yi-Ching]". Hun Yuan's website. Hun Yuan's website. [https://web.archive.org/web/20171214203559/http://hunyuan.tw/?disp=pwpeace&language=ENG&page=10 Archived on 14 December 2017]. and worship of the "Three Great Ancestors" ([[Yellow Emperor|Huangdi]], [[Yan Emperor|Yandi]] and [[Chi You|Chiyou]])."[http://www.cjs.org.tw/news2011/right_m_en/right_ch4_1_2.aspx Honoring the contribution of the Three-Great-Chinese-Ancestor Culture to develop world peace]". Hun Yuan's website. [https://web.archive.org/web/20171214203516/http://www.cjs.org.tw/news2011/right_m_en/right_ch4_1_2.aspx Archived on 14 December 2017]. It is defined by scholars as "the institutionalization of […] [[Chinese folk religion|diffuse folk beliefs]]".Chang (2016), p. 4. The movement promotes the restoration of the authentic roots of the Chinese civilization and [[Chinese reunification]]. ==Founding== [[File:Grand Master Hun Yuan.jpg|thumb|Grand Master Hun Yuan]] Weixinism was founded in the 1980s, in a context where the end of [[martial law in Taiwan]], with the consequent affirmation of [[freedom of religion]], allowed several new religious movements to operate openly and eventually to gain legal recognition. At the same time, in the aftermath of the [[Cultural Revolution]] in the mainland, several local new religious movements presented themselves as the guardians of Chinese "orthodoxy" in religious beliefs, intended as the genuine religious and cultural tradition that had developed throughout centuries of Chinese history. Among the most successful of such movementsIntrovigne (2016). was Weixinism, which was founded as the result of the mystical experiences of Chang Yi-Jui, born in [[Zhongliao, Nantou]], Taiwan, in 1944, and later known as Grand Master Hun Yuan. Before falling seriously ill in 1982, Chang, who operated a land survey company in Taiwan, was not particularly religious, although he had been interested for years in ''[[Yijing]]'' and ''[[fengshui]]''.Chang (2016), p. 5. He attributed his recovery to a miraculous intervention and vowed to dedicate his remaining life to spirituality.Huang (2016), p. 94. He claimed to have received messages both from the [[Chinese theology#Yudi|Jade Deity]], one of the representations of the [[Chinese theology|supreme God]], and from [[Guiguzi]], a name that indicates both a group of writings compiled between the late [[Warring States]] period and the end of the [[Han Dynasty]] and their author, later deified in Chinese folk religion. Feeling he was now mystically united with Guiguzi, Chang opened a small worship hall in Taichung and started gathering followers. In 1984, he renamed the hall [[Shennong]] Temple and claimed to have received by divine revelation the name and title of Grand Master Hun Yuan.Introvigne (2016). In 1987, he registered his movement as Weixinism, a name meaning "Heart(or Mind)-Only" teaching.Introvigne (2016). In 1989, the headquarters were moved to larger facilities in [[Nantou County]], in a complex known as the Hsien Fo Temple. The movement’s growth led to the establishment of some forty branch temples in Taiwan, and overseas branches in China, Japan, Vietnam, Australia, the United States, Canada, and Spain.Introvigne (2016). A variety of temples, including a large headquarters complex known as the "City (or Temple) of the Eight Symbols" on Yumen Mountain in [[Henan]], have been built in mainland China since 2001.Introvigne (2016). Another headquarters complex has been built in 2008 in [[Nantou City]], Taiwan.Huang (2016), p. 61. ==Education and society== [[File:Main temple of the City of the Eight Symbols (八卦城), the holy see of Weixinism (唯心教) in Hebi (鹤壁市), Henan, China.jpg|thumb|The City of the Eight Symbols in [[Qi County, Hebi|Qi]], [[Hebi]], is the headquarters of the Weixinist Church in [[Henan]], mainland China.]] Weixinism success is largely due to it having emerged as a leading provider of courses on ''Yijing'' and ''fengshui'', two systems that are immensely popular both in Taiwan and in China and among the international Chinese diaspora, and increasingly interest Westerners as well.Introvigne (2016). Academic courses are offered through the Weixinist College, which has been accredited in 2013 by the [[Ministry of Education (Taiwan)|Ministry of Education of Taiwan]],Chang (2016), p. 5; Ministry of Education (Taiwan) 2013. while the I Ching University proposes "lifelong learning" seminars and coordinates courses offering ''Yijing'' teaching to children. Two million children have attended such courses between their launching in 1996 and 2016.Ling (2013), p. 76. Weixinism has also organized a number of academic conferences, featuring scholars from Taiwan, Mainland China, Korea, and the West.Huang (2016), pp. 61–62. The church's educational effort also includes the publication of several books by Grand Master Hun Yuan and the daily television programs ''View All Perspectives of I Ching – Feng Shui'' (1998), ''Everybody Comes to Learn I Ching'' (1998), and ''Feng Shui of My Home'' (digital, 2004), as well as the group’s own TV channel, Wei Xin TV.Introvigne (2016). The Weixinist Church insists that ''Yijing'' should be taught not only as a philosophical system, but as a practical tool for divination, and that ''fengshui'' goes beyond the harmonious arrangement of buildings and furniture, and is in fact a complete system teaching how to live in harmony with nature.Chang (2016), p. 5; Hun Yuan (2016b). Weixinism's notion of ''fengshui'' also motivated the movement to establish in 1999, in the aftermath of the devastating [[1999 Jiji earthquake]], the I Ching and Feng Shui Interest Circle, which later evolved into the Feng Shui Interest Circle Service Team. The organization offers advise on how to build [[anti-seismic]] buildings according to the principles of ''fengshui'', but also helps needy families in both Taiwan and Mainland China.Huang (2016), p. 40. Other programs are aimed at improving the conditions in Taiwanese factories and other workplaces by applying the principles of ''fengshui'' there.Huang (2016), p. 57. Weixinism worships Guiguzi who, according to the tradition, operated the first school of diplomacy in the world. One of the main activities of the movement is the promotion of initiatives for the spiritual reconciliation of Taiwan and mainland China, which is seen as a pre-condition for the solution of political problems. The Taiwan Weixin Association for World Peace has been established in 2009. Its goals go beyond local problems in Taiwan and include the promotion of world peace through the healing of grievances and resentments deriving from centuries of war and conflict.Huang (2016), p. 74. ==Doctrines== {{Further|Chinese theology|Wufang Shangdi}} Weixinist theology is rooted in a mythical history of Chinese culture and civilization, largely derived from the tradition of Chinese folk religion. This history starts with the ''[[Kunlun Mountain (mythology)|Kunlun]]''. The Kunlun civilization is said to have flourished in remote times at the beginning of human history. Kunlun’s wisdom was inherited by [[Fuxi]], a king in the third millennium BCE and reputedly the originator of the ''Yijing'', and transmitted by him through [[Jiutian Xuannü]], the goddess of longevity incarnated on Earth, to the Three Ancestors of China: the ''[[Yan Emperor|Yandi]]'' ("Flame God"), the ''[[Yellow Emperor|Huangdi]]'' ("Yellow God") and ''[[Chiyou]]''.Introvigne (2016). The latter, Chiyou, is regarded in Chinese folk religion as an enemy against whom the Flame and Yellow Emperors had to fight. One of the peculiarities of Weixinism is its rehabilitation of Chiyou. He is regarded as the ancestor of China's ethnic minorities and the healing of the wounds left by the conflicts and wars that accompanied Chinese history requires, according to the movement, that Chiyou be worshiped as equal in dignity to the Yan and Yellow Emperors.Chang (2016), pp. 8–9. Guiguzi, according to Weixinist doctrines, was the legitimate heir of the Three Emperors. The awakened being Wang Chan Lao Chu incarnated in Guiguzi and is now mysteriously united with Grand Master Hun Yuan. The unbroken line connecting Kunlun to present-day Weixinism through the Three Ancestors and Guiguzi should guarantee that the movement embodies the most traditional Chinese "orthodoxy". The Three Ancestors are said to be at the origins also of the Japanese, Vietnamese, and Korean earliest royal families, thus incorporating a good part of the Far East within the same lineage.Introvigne (2016). The revelation of Guiguzi to Grand Master Hun Yuan and the latter's writings, also said to be inspired by Guiguzi, form an impressive corpus. It includes sixteen ''Apocalypse Scriptures'' and more than 18,000 volumes of speeches, writings, and comments of Grand Master Hun Yuan. Most of what he says is faithfully recorded by his followers and included in these collected works, known as ''Weixin Canon'', and continuously growing.Huang (2010–). ==Rituals== [[File:United Ancestor Worship Cerimony Taipei 2017 01.jpg|thumb|The annual United Ancestor Worship Ceremony organized by Weixin Shengjiao in Taipei, 2017.]] Taiwanese scholars have interpreted Weixinism as an institutionalized form of traditional, non-institutional Chinese folk religion, "the institutionalization of […] diffuse folk beliefs". Ritual, including chanting, is central in the movement. It includes daily ritual services at the headquarters and in the branch temples, as well as larger and more elaborate ceremonies. The movement believes that the systematic chanting of mantras by its members has averted or alleviated a number of world catastrophes.Hun Yuan (2016a), pp. 149–154. Starting in 2004, the Weixinist Church has organized each year on January 1 in Taipei's Linkou Stadium the "Unified Ancestor Worship Ceremony for Chinese in the 21st Century", to bring peace to the souls of all ancestors, particularly those who perished in the many wars fought during Chinese history. These spectacular ceremonies draw crowds in excess of 30,000 each year. Presidents of the republic of Taiwan, cabinet ministers, and other political leaders have also participated.See Weixin Shengjiao (2004), p. 90, and Weixin Shengjiao (2008), p. 54. Introvigne wrote that the ceremony "attracts great crowds. Taiwanese political dignitaries, including presidents of the Republic, have also participated in the event" (Introvigne, 2016). According to Fiona Chang, "this is a major event for ancestral worship and is also a carnival that mobilizes over 30 thousand members of the religious group, inviting politicians and businessmen from around the world, as well as representatives of Chinese religious groups" (Chang, 2016, p. 8). Weixinism believes that ancestor worship ceremonies have a crucial role in promoting world peace and ushering in a future millennial era without conflicts that would last for 5,000 years.Huang (2016), p. 89. ==See also== * [[Chinese folk religion]] * [[Chinese salvationist religions]] ==References== ===Citations=== {{Reflist|30em}} ===Sources=== *Chang, Hsin-Fang Fiona (2016).
